paper_title: Multifunctional 2D porous g-C3N4 nanosheets hybridized with 3D hierarchical TiO2 microflowers for selective dye adsorption, antibiotic degradation and CO2 reduction

light source.source: Photocatalytic tests for TC degradation were performed using a PLS-SXE300 Xe lamp (Beijing Perfectlight Technology Co., Ltd.) equipped with a UV cut-off filter as the visible light source ( 420 nm).
light source.context: Melamine, K 2 CO 3 , KCl, NaOH, methyl orange (MO), methylene blue (MB), Rhodamine B (RhB), Tetracycline (TC) and HNO 3 (65 -68) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.TiO 2 was obtained from Xiya Reagent.Anhydrous methanol, 5,5-dimethyl-1pyrroline-N-oxide (DMPO) and terephthalic acid (TA) were purchased from Adamas-beta Reagent.The above chemical reagents were of analytical grade and used without further purification.Deionized (DI) water was utilized throughout the experiments. Bulk g-C 3 N 4 sample (named as BCN) was synthesized by direct thermal polymerization of melamine and K 2 Ti 6 O 13 sample (named as KTO) was obtained by a facile KCl molten salt method using K 2 CO 3 and TiO 2 as precursors, as described in our previous reports 10,36,40.The 3D/2D TiO 2 /p-g-C 3 N 4 micro-nano HAs were fabricated via a facile acid hydrothermal method.Firstly, a certain amount of the as-prepared KTO and BCN powders were homogeneously dispersed in HNO 3 aqueous solution (6.0 M, 75 mL) by ultrasonication and magnetic stirring at room temperature.Then, the obtained suspension was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (100 mL) and subsequently heated in a oven at 140 C for 18 h.After that, the resultant products were filtered and washed with DI water repeatedly to completely remove residual acid.Finally, the obtained sample was dried at 80 C for 12 h.According to the mass ratio of KTO to BCN (1/100, 1/80, 1/50, 1/20), the as-prepared samples were named as TOCN-100, TOCN-80, TOCN-50, TOCN-20, respectively.Pure BCN and KTO samples subjected to the same hydrothermal process were named as HCN and HTO, respectively. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed using a Rigaku D/ max-2550 VB/PC diffractometer with Cu-K radiation ( 1.5406A).Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was recorded on a Perkin-Elmer (Pyris Diamond) thermal analyzer at a heating rate of 10 C min -1 from 50 to 800 C in air.Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images and energy dispersive X-ray spectra (EDS) were obtained using Hitachi S-3400, Philips XL30 FEG and NOVANano SEM450 electron microscopes equipped with an EDAX Genesis XM2 detector.Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were collected on JEOL JEM-2100 and JEM-2100F electron microscopes operated at 200 kV.Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was measured on a Nicolet 6700 spectrometer using KBr pellets.Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra were recorded on a JEOL FA200 spectrometer at room temperature.Nitrogen adsorption-desorption analysis was measured on a Micromeritics ASAP 2010 surface area and porosity analyzer at 77 K. UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) was performed on a Perkin-Elmer Lambda 950 spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere.X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was conducted on a Thermo ESCALAB 250 photoelectron spectrometer.Photoluminescence (PL) spectra were performed on a Perkin-Elmer LS-55 spectrofluorometer under the excitation at 325 nm.DMPO in methanol was used to detect superoxide (O 2 -) radicals formed during the photocatalytic reactions, and the corresponding ESR spectra were recorded on a Bruker EMX-8/2.7 spectrometer.To capture the formed hydroxyl radicals (OH) in the photocatalytic systems, PL spectra were measured by Shimadzu RF-5301PC spectrofluorophotometer using TA as a probe molecule under the excitation at 315 nm.CO 2 temperature programmed desorption (CO 2 -TPD) was performed using a Micrometrics AutoChem II 2920 instrument. As a typical anionic dye, MO was used to evaluate the adsorption properties of the as-synthesized samples at room temperature.Typically, 10 mg of catalyst was ultrasonically dispersed into 50 mL of MO aqueous solution (10 mg L -1 ) at netural pH and then the suspension was stirred continuously.At a given time interval, ca. 4 mL of suspension was withdrawn and centrifuged, followed by further filtration with a 0.22 m syringe filter (pretreated by MO dye).The concentration of the residual MO was determined using a Lambda 950 spectrophotometer at the maximum wavelength ( max ) of 464 nm, according to the calibration curve between the max absorbance and concentration of MO.The dye removal percentage ( dye , ) and adsorption capacity (q t , mg g -1 ) were calculated by the following equations: where m (g) is the mass of adsorbent; V (L) is the volume of dye aqueous solution; C 0 and C t (mg L -1 ) are the initial concentration of dye solution and dye concentration at contact time t (min), respectively. Photocatalytic tests for TC degradation were performed using a PLS-SXE300 Xe lamp (Beijing Perfectlight Technology Co., Ltd.) equipped with a UV cut-off filter as the visible light source ( 420 nm).Typically, 40 mg of sample was put into 80 mL of TC aqueous solution (C 0 20 mg L -1 ) and then the suspension was magnetically stirred for 1 h in the dark to establish an adsorption-desorption equilibrium between catalysts and TC molecules.The photocatalytic tests were conducted in a customized quartz reactor that was kept at 25C by a flow of cooling water and covered by aluminum foil to enhance light absorption of the reaction sysytem.At a specific time interval, clear TC solution was collected by centrifugation and filtration.The concentrations of TC solutions were measured on the Lambda 950 instrument to calculate the degradation efficiency ( TC , ) based on the equation: where C e and C are the equilibrium and time-dependent concentrations of TC solutions, respectively. The photocatalytic tests for CO 2 reduction were performed in a customized airtight reactor (135 mL) with an optical quartz window at the top.In a typical test, 30 mg of catalyst was uniformly coated on a square quartz plate (2.5 2.5 cm 2 ) and placed at the bottom of the reactor.Prior to light irradiation, the reaction system was flushed by N 2 gas, and then high-purity CO 2 (99.99) was bubbled through DI water for 30 min to fill the reactor with gaseous CO 2 and H 2 O.After that, such a reaction system was allowed to stand for the adsorption-desorption equilibrium between catalyst and CO 2 /H 2 O.A CEL-HXF300 Xe lamp (Beijing China Education Aulight Co., Ltd.) equipped with a 420 nm cutoff filter was employed to provide the visible light irradiation with an average light intensity of 210 mW cm -2 at the upper position of catalyst film (CEL-NP2000 optical power meter, Beijing China Education Aulight Co., Ltd.).The reaction temperature was kept at 15 C using a DC-0506 low-temperature thermostat bath.At each time interval, 1 mL of gas was extracted from the reactor and quantified by a Shimadzu GC-2014 gas chromatography equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID).The reduction products was quantified by the external standard with a calibration curve. The PEC tests were performed by an electrochemical workstation (Solartron 1260/1287) in a standard three-electrode quartz cell using a saturated Ag/AgCl electrode, a Pt plate and the catalyst film deposited on an ITO substrate as reference electrode, counter electrode and working electrode, respectively.Before each test, the working electrode was immersed in the electrolyte (1.0 M NaOH, pH 13.6) until the open-circuit potential (V oc ) reached a steady state.The Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was recorded with AC amplitude of 10 mV at a frequency range of 100 kHz 0.1 Hz under light irradiation.The V oc , linear sweep voltammagrams (LSV), transient photocurrent responses and EIS were measured with the working electrodes irradiated from their back sides to decrease the thickness effect of catalyst films.A 300 W Xe lamp equipped with a 400 nm cutoff filter was used as the visible light source for PEC measurements.The measured potentials vs. Ag/AgCl electrode (E Ag/AgCl ) were converted to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) scale according to the Nernst equation: E RHE E Ag/AgCl 0.059 pH E 0 Ag/AgCl , where E RHE is the converted potential vs. RHE, E 0 Ag/AgCl is 0.1976 V for the Ag/AgCl electrode (saturated KCl) at 25 C.

light source.source: Importantly, TiO 2 /p-g-C 3 N 4 composites show remarkably enhanced visible-light photocatalytic performances towards both antibiotic degradation and CO 2 reduction.
light source.context: In summary, 2D p-g-C 3 N 4 NSs hybridized with 3D hierarchical TiO 2 MFs were successfully fabricated through a one-pot hydrothermal method using K 2 Ti 6 O 13 NBs and g-C 3 N 4 bulks as precursors.Abundant porous structures, surface C vacancies and interfacial heterojunctions are constructed in the micro-nano TiO 2 /p-g-C 3 N 4 HAs.Interestingly, the hydrothermally produced p-g-C 3 N 4 NSs show excellent selective MO adsorption while the introduction of TiO 2 MFs exhibits a negative effect on their adsorption capability.Importantly, TiO 2 /p-g-C 3 N 4 composites show remarkably enhanced visible-light photocatalytic performances towards both antibiotic degradation and CO 2 reduction.The excellent adsorption and photocatalytic properties of multifunctional 3D/2D TiO 2 /p-g-C 3 N 4 HAs are mainly attributed to the positively charged surface, enlarged surface area and pore volume (more adsorption/active sites), improved light absorption and especially the enhanced charge separation efficiency based on interfacial heterojunctions and surface C vacancies.This work may provide an attractive pathway to design multifunctional g-C 3 N 4 -based composites via the synergy of composition, structure and defect engineering for highly efficient environmental remediation and solar-to-fuel conversion. (a) UV-vis DRS and estimated band gaps (inset); (b) XPS VB spectra, (c) Schematic of energy band alignments; (d) PL spectra of the as-prepared samples.Note: E 0 (pH 7) E 0 (pH 0) -0.0597 (V vs. NHE).1 Fig.8b, the VB of both BCN and HCN are ca.2.26 eV, suggesting that the acid hydrothermal treatment has no contribution to engineering the VB of g-C 3 N 4 .The measured VB positions were converted to the normal hydrogen electrode (NHE) scale at pH 7,53,54 and the detailed band structure alignments of BCN and HCN are illustrated in Fig.8c.Obviously, the band-edge positions of HCN could trigger various redox reductions including water splitting, CO 2 reduction and the generation of reactive radicals for pollutant degradation.Notably, the small difference in CB between BCN and HCN could be ascribed to the formation of feeble C vacancies since the CB of CN is predominated by C 2p orbitals.Thus, the more negative CB of HCN (in relative to that of BCN) could endow it with stronger reduction ability for the generation of reactive radicals towards pollutant degradation and the conversion of CO 2 gas into hydrocarbon fuels.In addition, PL spectra (shown in Fig.8d) were employed to evaluate the recombination/separation behaviors and lifetime of charge carriers in the light-excited catalyst samples.55Firstly, it can be seen that the emission peak of HCN has blue-shifted from ca. 465 to 460 nm in comparison with BCN, mainly due to the formation of smaller particles with porous nanoarchitectures in HCN, which is consistent with UV-vis DRS results.In general, the lower PL emission peak the higher separation efficiency of photogenerated electron-hole pairs.Evidently, HCN and its composites exhibit the weaker emission intensity than BCN, which is characteristic of the remarkable increased charge separation efficiency in g-C 3 N 4 materials after the acid hydrothermal treatment.Thus, TOCN-80 with the lowest PL emission peak implies the possibly highest photocatalytic performance.From the above results, it can be concluded that, not only the morphological features but the electronic band structures of g-C 3 N 4 have been successfully tailored via the acid hydrothermal process, which would naturally promote the surface adsorption, photocatalytic and photoelectrochemical performances. Fig.8b, the VB of both BCN and HCN are ca.2.26 eV, suggesting that the acid hydrothermal treatment has no contribution to engineering the VB of g-C 3 N 4 .The measured VB positions were converted to the normal hydrogen electrode (NHE) scale at pH 7,53,54 and the detailed band structure alignments of BCN and HCN are illustrated in Fig.8c.Obviously, the band-edge positions of HCN could trigger various redox reductions including water splitting, CO 2 reduction and the generation of reactive radicals for pollutant degradation.Notably, the small difference in CB between BCN and HCN could be ascribed to the formation of feeble C vacancies since the CB of CN is predominated by C 2p orbitals.Thus, the more negative CB of HCN (in relative to that of BCN) could endow it with stronger reduction ability for the generation of reactive radicals towards pollutant degradation and the conversion of CO 2 gas into hydrocarbon fuels.In addition, PL spectra (shown in Fig.8d) were employed to 465 to 460 nm in comparison with BCN, mainly due to the formation of smaller particles with porous nanoarchitectures in HCN, which is consistent with UV-vis DRS results.In general, the lower PL emission peak the higher separation efficiency of photogenerated electron-hole pairs.Evidently, HCN and its composites exhibit the weaker emission intensity than BCN, which is characteristic of the remarkable increased charge separation efficiency in g-C 3 N 4 materials after the acid hydrothermal treatment.Thus, TOCN-80 with the lowest PL emission peak implies the possibly highest photocatalytic performance.From the above results, it can be concluded that, not only the morphological features but the electronic band structures of g-C 3 N 4 have been successfully tailored via the acid hydrothermal process, which would naturally promote the surface adsorption, photocatalytic and photoelectrochemical performances. reactor type.context: Melamine, K 2 CO 3 , KCl, NaOH, methyl orange (MO), methylene blue (MB), Rhodamine B (RhB), Tetracycline (TC) and HNO 3 (65 -68) were purchased from Sinopharm Chemical Reagent Co., Ltd.TiO 2 was obtained from Xiya Reagent.Anhydrous methanol, 5,5-dimethyl-1pyrroline-N-oxide (DMPO) and terephthalic acid (TA) were purchased from Adamas-beta Reagent.The above chemical reagents were of analytical grade and used without further purification.Deionized (DI) water was utilized throughout the experiments. Bulk g-C 3 N 4 sample (named as BCN) was synthesized by direct thermal polymerization of melamine and K 2 Ti 6 O 13 sample (named as KTO) was obtained by a facile KCl molten salt method using K 2 CO 3 and TiO 2 as precursors, as described in our previous reports 10,36,40.The 3D/2D TiO 2 /p-g-C 3 N 4 micro-nano HAs were fabricated via a facile acid hydrothermal method.Firstly, a certain amount of the as-prepared KTO and BCN powders were homogeneously dispersed in HNO 3 aqueous solution (6.0 M, 75 mL) by ultrasonication and magnetic stirring at room temperature.Then, the obtained suspension was transferred to a Teflon-lined stainless steel autoclave (100 mL) and subsequently heated in a oven at 140 C for 18 h.After that, the resultant products were filtered and washed with DI water repeatedly to completely remove residual acid.Finally, the obtained sample was dried at 80 C for 12 h.According to the mass ratio of KTO to BCN (1/100, 1/80, 1/50, 1/20), the as-prepared samples were named as TOCN-100, TOCN-80, TOCN-50, TOCN-20, respectively.Pure BCN and KTO samples subjected to the same hydrothermal process were named as HCN and HTO, respectively. Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) was performed using a Rigaku D/ max-2550 VB/PC diffractometer with Cu-K radiation ( 1.5406A).Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was recorded on a Perkin-Elmer (Pyris Diamond) thermal analyzer at a heating rate of 10 C min -1 from 50 to 800 C in air.Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images and energy dispersive X-ray spectra (EDS) were obtained using Hitachi S-3400, Philips XL30 FEG and NOVANano SEM450 electron microscopes equipped with an EDAX Genesis XM2 detector.Transmission electron microscopy (TEM) images were collected on JEOL JEM-2100 and JEM-2100F electron microscopes operated at 200 kV.Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was measured on a Nicolet 6700 spectrometer using KBr pellets.Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) spectra were recorded on a JEOL FA200 spectrometer at room temperature.Nitrogen adsorption-desorption analysis was measured on a Micromeritics ASAP 2010 surface area and porosity analyzer at 77 K. UV-vis diffuse reflectance spectroscopy (DRS) was performed on a Perkin-Elmer Lambda 950 spectrophotometer equipped with an integrating sphere.X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was conducted on a Thermo ESCALAB 250 photoelectron spectrometer.Photoluminescence (PL) spectra were performed on a Perkin-Elmer LS-55 spectrofluorometer under the excitation at 325 nm.DMPO in methanol was used to detect superoxide (O 2 -) radicals formed during the photocatalytic reactions, and the corresponding ESR spectra were recorded on a Bruker EMX-8/2.7 spectrometer.To capture the formed hydroxyl radicals (OH) in the photocatalytic systems, PL spectra were measured by Shimadzu RF-5301PC spectrofluorophotometer using TA as a probe molecule under the excitation at 315 nm.CO 2 temperature programmed desorption (CO 2 -TPD) was performed using a Micrometrics AutoChem II 2920 instrument. As a typical anionic dye, MO was used to evaluate the adsorption properties of the as-synthesized samples at room temperature.Typically, 10 mg of catalyst was ultrasonically dispersed into 50 mL of MO aqueous solution (10 mg L -1 ) at netural pH and then the suspension was stirred continuously.At a given time interval, ca. 4 mL of suspension was withdrawn and centrifuged, followed by further filtration with a 0.22 m syringe filter (pretreated by MO dye).The concentration of the residual MO was determined using a Lambda 950 spectrophotometer at the maximum wavelength ( max ) of 464 nm, according to the calibration curve between the max absorbance and concentration of MO.The dye removal percentage ( dye , ) and adsorption capacity (q t , mg g -1 ) were calculated by the following equations: where m (g) is the mass of adsorbent; V (L) is the volume of dye aqueous solution; C 0 and C t (mg L -1 ) are the initial concentration of dye solution and dye concentration at contact time t (min), respectively. Photocatalytic tests for TC degradation were performed using a PLS-SXE300 Xe lamp (Beijing Perfectlight Technology Co., Ltd.) equipped with a UV cut-off filter as the visible light source ( 420 nm).Typically, 40 mg of sample was put into 80 mL of TC aqueous solution (C 0 20 mg L -1 ) and then the suspension was magnetically stirred for 1 h in the dark to establish an adsorption-desorption equilibrium between catalysts and TC molecules.The photocatalytic tests were conducted in a customized quartz reactor that was kept at 25C by a flow of cooling water and covered by aluminum foil to enhance light absorption of the reaction sysytem.At a specific time interval, clear TC solution was collected by centrifugation and filtration.The concentrations of TC solutions were measured on the Lambda 950 instrument to calculate the degradation efficiency ( TC , ) based on the equation: where C e and C are the equilibrium and time-dependent concentrations of TC solutions, respectively. The photocatalytic tests for CO 2 reduction were performed in a customized airtight reactor (135 mL) with an optical quartz window at the top.In a typical test, 30 mg of catalyst was uniformly coated on a square quartz plate (2.5 2.5 cm 2 ) and placed at the bottom of the reactor.Prior to light irradiation, the reaction system was flushed by N 2 gas, and then high-purity CO 2 (99.99) was bubbled through DI water for 30 min to fill the reactor with gaseous CO 2 and H 2 O.After that, such a reaction system was allowed to stand for the adsorption-desorption equilibrium between catalyst and CO 2 /H 2 O.A CEL-HXF300 Xe lamp (Beijing China Education Aulight Co., Ltd.) equipped with a 420 nm cutoff filter was employed to provide the visible light irradiation with an average light intensity of 210 mW cm -2 at the upper position of catalyst film (CEL-NP2000 optical power meter, Beijing China Education Aulight Co., Ltd.).The reaction temperature was kept at 15 C using a DC-0506 low-temperature thermostat bath.At each time interval, 1 mL of gas was extracted from the reactor and quantified by a Shimadzu GC-2014 gas chromatography equipped with a flame ionization detector (FID).The reduction products was quantified by the external standard with a calibration curve. The PEC tests were performed by an electrochemical workstation (Solartron 1260/1287) in a standard three-electrode quartz cell using a saturated Ag/AgCl electrode, a Pt plate and the catalyst film deposited on an ITO substrate as reference electrode, counter electrode and working electrode, respectively.Before each test, the working electrode was immersed in the electrolyte (1.0 M NaOH, pH 13.6) until the open-circuit potential (V oc ) reached a steady state.The Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy (EIS) was recorded with AC amplitude of 10 mV at a frequency range of 100 kHz 0.1 Hz under light irradiation.The V oc , linear sweep voltammagrams (LSV), transient photocurrent responses and EIS were measured with the working electrodes irradiated from their back sides to decrease the thickness effect of catalyst films.A 300 W Xe lamp equipped with a 400 nm cutoff filter was used as the visible light source for PEC measurements.The measured potentials vs. Ag/AgCl electrode (E Ag/AgCl ) were converted to the reversible hydrogen electrode (RHE) scale according to the Nernst equation: E RHE E Ag/AgCl 0.059 pH E 0 Ag/AgCl , where E RHE is the converted potential vs. RHE, E 0 Ag/AgCl is 0.1976 V for the Ag/AgCl electrode (saturated KCl) at 25 C.
